data.text: Contents
Introduction
Diathermy is a piece of electrical equipment, primarily used to aid haemostasis during an operative procedure. In some cases it may be used as a tool for cutting through tissue.

Monopolar diathermy is used to coagulate larger areas and for use as a cutting tool. Bipolar diathermy is normally used for very precise coagulation of smaller operations areas, e.g. paediatrics, plastic surgery and ophthalmology.
The purpose

The purpose of this document is to facilitate the safe use of electro-surgical equipment units and associated equipment within the peri-operative setting. This will ensure that staff will protect all patients whose surgery requires the use of diathermy, rom the risk of burns.

Diathermy can be a hazard to the user and the patient if used incorrectly. Therefore, safety checks must be made and it must only be used by medically qualified personnel, who know what precautions to take and how to avoid dangers and risks to the patient.
Definitions

table_items.text: Uses an electrical current between the tips of the forceps, to the point of contact and back again. One side of the forcep is positively charged the other is negative, and so the electrical current passess from one side to the other. Voltage is low and no diathermy plate is required. This method provides cautery with less risk of heating tissue peripheral to the site and is preferred for finer plastic surgery No diathermy pad required

Electrosurgery (diathermy) is the cutting and coagulation of the body tissue with a high frequency electrical current. The high frequency. The high frequency current operates at 300,000Hz or higher (radio frequency) .At this high frequency rate, neither the nervous system nor the muscle is affected when the current is passed through the body.

Monopolar uses a high frequency current; patients must have an earth plate attached. The electrical current passes from the diathermy machine via the live electrode (forceps or diathermy tip) then back to the earth plate and diathermy machine, thus creating a full circuit. Coagulation occurs through creating a high temperature at the point where electricity enters the body.
Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust
Ultrasound equipment can also cut and coagulate tissue using high frequency sound waves, for example the

Harmonic Scalpel,Thunderbeat and Ligasure. These facilitate the transformation of electrical energy into mechanical energy, and this transformation usually occure in the hand piece following activation of the footswitch or hand control by the user. Coblation is a type of ultrasound used within a conductive medium such as saline. Ultrasound equipment is designed for both open and laparoscopic procedures.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the MSE Trust

The Trust Board is collectively responsible for safeguarding patients and ensuring that MSE has a robust, complete and up to date procedures in place to govern and guild activities so that legal and national requirements are meet.
MSE Document Group is responsible for updating and reviewing this policy in line with national guidelines.
Theatre and Anaesthetics (T&A) Division Governance Committee is responsible for ensuring this policy is regularly updated and reviewed.

Chief Executive-has the overall responsibility for ensuring the MSE Hospital NHS Foundation trust has robust and up to date procedural documents in place to govern and guide staff and protect patients.

Executive Directors are responsible for ensuring all procedural documents under their remit are appropriate, up to date and available. They are also referred to as the sponsor. Who ensures policies are reviewed in a timely manner and for overseeing their development and implementation

General Managers – must implement this policy and identify training needs and assessing against what the service is delivering. Surgeons are responsible for the training and support of junior staff they are supervising ensuring they adhere to this policy and have appropriate training to ensure patient and staff safety
Theatre staff- Must ensure they have read and understood this policy and adhere to it at all times, in line with health and safety and understanding their learning and training needs
Equipment risk manager – must ensure all equipment is tested regularly in line with trust polices
Monopolar mode and procedure
Monopolar has three modes for cutting and three for coagulation to allow a wide range of power settings for a variety of surgical procedures;
Cut modes
5.2.1 Low- for a cut with little or no spark, used for delicate or laparoscopic surgery
5.2.2 Pure-when a precise cut is required in any tissue with little or no haemostatasis
5.2.3 Bleed-where slower cutting and additional haemostasis is required
Coagulation
5.3.1 Desiccate-destroys tissue without spark or cutting, more current reaches the patient, desiccation places greatest demand on the earth plate for returning current.
5.3.2 Fulgurate (destroy) – coagulates by sparking from the active electrode (forcep or tip of pencilette), diathermy effect can spread to peripheral tissue as tissue at the surgical site dries.
5.3.3 Spray – allows optimum fulguration, penetration is less deep and tissue area is larger than the fulgurate mode.
5.3.4 All settings and modes are set at the surgeons preference for the procedure and can change throughout the operation
Process
Equipment needed:
Electrosurgical unit/Diathermy machine
Earth lead
Disposable diathermy plate/appropriate for size of patient/paediatric plates are available for monopolar
Electric Razor and sticky hand to collect hair
Hazards of electrosurgery, burns

Accidental burns are the greatest risk to patients, and have the potential to cause pain and disfigurement. Accidental burns still occur despite advances in technology that have produced safe and efficient electrosurgical equipment. (MHRA 2005a)
The main cause of accidental burns is poor practice carried out by surgeons or practitioners with little or no knowledge or experience of the principles of electrosurgery (MDA 1998/2002).
Smoke evacuation is recommended for safety of staff.
Quivers or a plastic receiver should be used routinely to keep the diathermy safe on the patient and help avoid risks of burns.
Cardiac implantable electronic devices (CIEDs)

The use of Cardiac Implantable Electronic Devices (CIEDs) for heart rhythm management include pacemakers for control of bradycardias (slow heart rates), implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICDs) for treatment of life-threatening ventricular tachycardias (fast heart rates), biventricular or resynchronisation pacemakers and ICDs for treatment of heart failure using ventricular resynchronisation (CRT-P and CRT-D respectively), implantable loop recorders(ILRs) and insertable cardiac monitors (ICMs) for monitoring cardiac arrhythmias. Precautions therefore need to be considered when procedures are carried out in which the patient may be exposed to electromagnetic interference (EMI).
Failure to plan the management of these devices may lead to inappropriate device function and or cause harm.

Where surgical diathermy/electrocautery is essential and is to be used at a site remote from the implanted device, then there is a low risk of an effect on the device which may lead to inappropriate function.
The use of bipolar surgical diathermy/electrocautery should be considered (in preference to monopolar) wherever possible, although there are still small risks attached to this (BHRS, 2016).

The majority of surgical procedures are planned in advance, patients having these devices should be identified through pre-admission screening, and the pre assessment nurses should follow the ‘Planned peri-operative management for patients who have a Cardiac Implantable Electronic Device' (see appendix 1). Temporary suspension or reprogramming of CIED's should take place as close to the time of surgery as possible and should ideally take place in the anaesthetic room. Where temporary suspension or reprogramming has been untaken, the patient must be monitored with continuous ECG monitoring before, during and after the operation. After the operation has finished, the Cardiac Physiologist should be contacted to advise them that the operation has finished and where the patient is being recovered. The CP will reprogram the CIED to the appropriate function settings prior to the patient leaving the recovery area.

Where diathermy/electrocautery is unavoidable, limit its use to short bursts and ensure that the return electrode is anatomically positioned so that the current pathway between the diathermy electrode and return electrode is as far away from the pacemaker/defibrillator (and leads) as possible. If detectable pacemaker inhibition occurs, the surgeon should be informed immediately and diathermy either used intermittently or discontinued.
Training requirements

As part of the theatre induction process, all new staff members will have training on the safe use of electrosurgical equipment within the perioperative environment. All staff will be educated as to the potential hazards of electrosurgery and equipment, how to preform safety checks, the correct procedure to follow on how to report faulty equipment. The training also includes the principles, procedures and techniques of eletrosurgery .
All new staff will be supervised, and will have competencies to complete regarding safe use of and application of diathermy
Medical staff receive training in electrosurgery as part of their clinical skills course
Preparation and use of electrosurgical equipment

Equipment must be prepared prior to use and used in accordance with manufacturer's instructions (MHRA 2003). All staff must have received training in the use of the equipment and records maintained as per Trust Policy.  All cables and electrodes must be checked prior to use to ensure there are no insulation defects, other defects and that they are in good working order  All equipment must be tested and maintained according to Trust Policy.
Safe practice
Single use, pre-gelled self-adhesive patient plates must be used. (MHRA 2005a)
The electrosurgical unit should be switched off or on standby before connecting the live surgical electrode.
All connections must be secured prior to the commencement of surgery.
The activation of the active electrode is the responsibility of the operating surgeon, their assistant, or a trained non-medical practitioner.
The active electrode must be housed in an insulated container (quiver), kept well away from the surgical field when not in use.
It is the responsibility of the user to ensure the active electrode is returned to the quiver after use.
Patient safety
The return electrode should be sighted as close as possible to the operative site.
The return electrode should be placed over in area which is well vascularised, such as a muscle mass. (upper legs, buttocks, stomach)

The return electrode should not be placed over scarred or damaged tissue. The site should be free from hair. Hair clippers are provided in each theatre for hair removal from the site of the return electrode.
The return electrode should not be placed close to the site of a metallic implant.

The return electrode must remain in direct contact with the patient's skin in order to ensure a safe return pathway for the current. If the electrosurgical unit alarm sounds or the patient is moved during surgery, the integrity of the return electrode must be rechecked.
The return electrode should only be applied after the patient is positioned for surgery in order to maintain direct contact with the patient.
The return electrode must remain dry during surgery. Care must be taken to prevent pooling of inflammable liquids in any cavity under the patient's body or under the electrode itself.

Alcoholic skin preparations and other alcohol based or aerosol products may ignite if they come into contact with sparks from electrosurgery. This can be avoided by not allowing alcoholic solutions to pool around the site of surgery while prepping the patient for surgery, and allowing them to dry or to be dried with a surgical swab prior to the start of the procedure. There is a risk that the surgical prep solution will not evaporate if covered with impervious single use drapes and therefore may ignite.
The patient must not come into contact with earthed metal objects during electrosurgery. This includes the operating table; table clamps trolleys, drip stands and mayo tables.

The return electrode should not be placed nearer to the ECG electrodes than the operating site as this increases the likelihood of alternative pathways being created, resulting in burns by the ECG electrodes.
Skin condition must be checked immediately before surgery and prior to leaving the theatre as part of the surgical sign out for the WHO Surgical Safety Checklist.
